Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism for Heterogeneously Catalyzed Sugar Alcohol Reactions: Hierarchical Modeling and Experimental Studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract Title: Molecular-level simulations of the chemistry of hydrogen generation from alcohols in aqueous solutions

Recent drivers of sustainability and environmental impact have led to processes for converting plant-derived chemicals into useful products for energy and specialty chemicals. In many cases, the technologies used to convert these compounds rely on expensive catalysts. For example, hydrogen for use as a pollutant-free fuel can be produced from plant-derived alcohols using catalysts comprised of platinum, palladium, rhodium, and other noble metals. The high costs of these catalyst materials percolate into the alcohol conversion costs, limiting the economic viability of these plant-derived raw materials, as well as their competitiveness with conventional petroleum-derived chemicals. Theoretically, less expensive conversion catalysts could be designed. One of the major challenges to finding good catalysts arises from the aqueous phase reaction environment used to process these plant-derived raw materials. These dense, aqueous environments significantly increase the number of molecules that are involved at the molecular level, making it difficult to evaluate their precise roles. This award is to Professors Rachel Getman and David Bruce of Clemson University to utilize a hierarchy of molecular simulation techniques as well as experiments to identify specific ways that water influences molecular-level chemistry for hydrogen production from methanol and glycerol, which are available byproducts of biofuel production. This study will also serve as an excellent training platform for undergraduate and graduate students, exposing them to computational and experimental techniques, and empowering them to intelligently address future scientific and societal problems. Web-based videos and presentations will enable a wider audience to follow the progress of the project and learn about key research findings. Future work will be aimed at designing less expensive catalysts for methanol and glycerol conversions as well as other solution-phase transformations.

Many catalyzed reactions occur in the liquid phase, and understanding molecular-level phenomena in liquids is at the forefront of catalysis research. Few fundamental reaction studies have explored how an aqueous solvent environment impacts the entropic and enthalpic driving forces involved in heterogeneous catalysis. To acquire the insight needed to optimize aqueous reaction systems, the objectives of this project are to elucidate the molecular-level mechanisms of two important aqueous phase reactions, specifically methanol oxidation and glycerol reforming, which are currently carried out over heterogeneous catalysts containing platinum and other noble metals (similar to many other reactions involved in biomass processing). This project employs a hierarchy of molecular-level modeling and experiments to identify the most prominent steps in the methanol oxidation and glycerol reforming mechanisms. Quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, Monte Carlo, and molecular dynamics will be used to model how the aqueous environment influences catalytic phenomena. Ultimately, quantum data and detailed microkinetic models will identify overall product selectivities, and simulation results will be compared with experimental observations for both validation and model improvement purposes. This research is potentially transformative in that it will elucidate adsorbate-intermediate interactions, adsorbate-fluid interactions, and their coupling, thus, providing a complete analysis of catalytic mechanisms in the liquid phase, and facilitating future work in catalyst design for a vital class of liquid phase reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project brought together experimentalists and computationalists to learn about fundamental aspects of catalysis, which is the science of making chemical reactions proceed more efficiently. Catalysis plays a significant role in our country's manufacturing base and contributes more than 35% to the GDP. In this project, we were specifically interested in learning about catalysis in aqueous solvent. With the push toward developing "greener" processing strategies, there is also a move to carry out catalytic reactions under mild conditions. As water is arguably the greenest solvent, by learning about the fundamentals of catalysis in aqueous phase, we can provide insight that will be useful in designing catalysts and reaction conditions for efficient operation in aqueous conditions.

Intellectual Merit

A main challenge in understanding how catalysts operate under aqueous phase is the large density of H2O molecules. Additionally, since the H2O molecules are in the liquid phase, they are under constant thermal motion. This makes understanding catalytic phenomena challenging, because H2O molecules interact with catalytic species and alter their energies, and these alterations depend on the precise configuration (a.k.a., the precise spatial arrangement) of the H2O molecules. Water molecules can additionally participate in catalytic reactions, and this also depends on how they arrange themselves around catalytic species. Understanding these phenomena requires being able to simulate them, which requires the ability to generate realistic configurations of liquid H2O molecules around a catalytic species of interest. This is further complicated since catalysis is inherently a quantum phenomenon, as it involves breaking and forming chemical bonds. To address these challenges, we developed a "multi-timescale" simulation technique, which couples classical molecular dynamics (cMD) with density functional theory (DFT), which is a quantum mechanics technique. Briefly, configurations of liquid H2O molecules are generated with cMD, and the energetics of bond breaking and forming processes are calculated with DFT. This method thus takes advantage of the strengths of both methods: cMD is computationally efficient and capable of generating many configurations of liquid H2O molecules, and DFT is accurate for calculating the energetics of bond breaking and forming.

We used the multi-timescale technique to simulate various phenomena related to aqueous phase catalysis. We showed that the energies of catalytic reactions are significantly impacted by hydrogen bonding. For example, when the reactants in a catalytic reaction form more hydrogen bonds with H2O molecules than the products, there is a significant energy penalty associated with the reaction due to the loss of hydrogen bonds over the course of the reaction. We also found that H2O molecules can facilitate certain types of catalytic reactions, specifically catalytic dehydrogenation (R-H → R + H) and hydrogenolysis reactions (R-OH → R + OH). These processes are significantly more facile when hydrogen bonds are present, indicating the importance of hydrogen bonding on catalytic kinetics. In contrast, we found that H2O molecules inhibit catalytic decarbonylation reactions (R-CO → R + CO). Specifically, H2O molecules have essentially 0 interaction energy with CO. Thus, when a CO group is cleaved from a catalytic species, the reaction incurs an energy penalty when carried out under aqueous phase. These insights were used to make hypotheses about the mechanism for the aqueous phase reforming of glycerol (C3H8O3 + 3H2O → 3CO2 + 7H2), which could provide a route for converting glycerol, which is presently a byproduct of biodiesel production and produced in surplus, into other valuable chemicals such as hydrogen gas.

Broader Impacts

This project explored fundamental aspects of aqueous phase catalysis, including how water molecules participate in the chemical reactions, thus providing useful insight. This project served as a training platform for 2 graduate students, 9 undergraduates, and 7 summer interns. Additionally, the project team worked with outreach groups on Clemson University's campus to provide short courses on catalysis research to college students from groups who are underrepresented in STEM education. Students were exposed to experimental research as well as multiple state-of-the-art methods in computational research, including multi-scale modeling, machine learning, and "big data" processing. The primary product from the project was the development of a multi-timescale method that enables simulation of catalytic processes under liquid conditions. This method has been documented in the peer reviewed literature. In addition to liquid phase catalysis, the method may find use in other fields where the governing phenomena are controlled by a balance between quantum level energies and molecular configurational disorder.
